solution: God is dead.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

solution: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.
author: Ludwig Wittgenstein

solution: Humankind cannot bear very much reality.
author: T. S. Eliot

solution: Enlightenment is man's emergence from his self-imposed immaturity.
source: An Answer to the Question: What Is Enlightenment?
author: Immanuel Kant

solution: Reality is ultimately water.
author: Thales

solution: I think, therefore I am.
author: Rene Descartes

solution: Free election of masters does not abolish the masters or the slaves. Free choice among a wide variety of goods and services does not signify freedom if these goods and services sustain social controls over a life of toil and fear – that is, if they sustain alienation.
source: One-Dimensional Man: Studies in the Ideology of Advanced Industrial Society
author: Herbert Marcuse

solution: A certificate tells me that I was born. I repudiate this certificate: I am not a poet, but a poem. A poem that is being written, even if it looks like a subject.
source: The Seminar of Jacques Lacan: The Four Fundamental Concepts of Psychoanalysis
author: Jacques Lacan

solution: It is important to read these eminent writers as engaging in a great imaginative effort. To read them as if they were just solving some technical puzzles or, as some people complain, “just playing with words,” is to misunderstand the way that we all see the world. For we all need a vision, a conceptual framework, to give facts and things meaning and make our lives worthwhile.
source: The Big Questions A Short Introduction to Philosophy
author: Robert C. Solomon

solution: The more powerful the class, the more it claims not to exist.
author: Guy Debord

solution: This society eliminates geographical distance only to produce a new internal separation.
author: Guy Debord

solution: Nature has placed mankind under the governance of two sovereign masters, pain and pleasure. It is for them alone to point out what we ought to do, as well as to determine what we shall do.
author: Jeremy Bentham

solution: But the life of a man is of no greater importance to the universe than that of an oyster.
author: David Hume

solution: Hell is—other people!
author: Jean-Paul Sartre

solution: Being all equal and independent, no one ought to harm another in his life, health, liberty, or possessions.
author: John Locke

solution: I am the wisest man alive, for I know one thing, and that is that I know nothing.
author: Plato

solution: Art does not simply reveal God: it is one of the ways in which God reveals, and thus actualizes, himself.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

solution: No one is more arrogant toward women, more aggressive or scornful, than the man who is anxious about his virility.
author: Simone de Beauvoir

solution: I seek not to instruct but only to lead, to point out and describe what I see. I claim no other right than that of speaking according to my best lights, principally before myself but in the same manner also before others, as one who has lived in all its seriousness the fate of a philosophical existence.
source: The Crisis of European Sciences and Transcendental Phenomenology
author: Edmund Husserl

solution: Reading the morning newspaper is the realist's morning prayer. One orients one's attitude toward the world either by God or by what the world is. The former gives as much security as the latter, in that one knows how one stands.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

solution: The philosophers have only interpreted the world, in various ways. The point, however, is to change it.
author: Karl Marx

solution: The less you eat, drink, buy books, go to the theatre or to balls, or to the pub, and the less you think, love, theorize, sing, paint, fence, etc., the more you will be able to save and the greater will become your treasure which neither moth nor rust will corrupt—your capital. The less you are, the less you express your life, the more you have, the greater is your alienated life and the greater is the saving of your alienated being.
author: Karl Marx

solution: It is not the consciousness of men that determines their being, but, on the contrary, their social being that determines their consciousness.
source: A Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy
author: Karl Marx

solution: It is solely by risking life that freedom is obtained; . . . the individual who has not staked his or her life may, no doubt, be recognized as a Person; but he or she has not attained the truth of this recognition as an independent self-consciousness.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

solution: Beauty is no quality in things themselves: It exists merely in the mind which contemplates them; and each mind perceives a different beauty.
source: Of the Standard of Taste and Other Essays
author: David Hume

solution: It is now some years since I detected how many were the false beliefs that I had from my earliest youth admitted as true, and how doubtful was everything I had since constructed on this basis: and from that time I was convinced that I must for once and for all seriously undertake to rid myself of all the opinions which I had formerly accepted and commence to build anew.
author: Rene Descartes

solution: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

solution: Human beings should be treated as an end in themselves and not as a means to something else.
author: Immanuel Kant

solution: In the end one loves one's desire and not what is desired.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

solution: Our search for the human takes us too far, too 'deep' , we seek it in the clouds or in mysteries, whereas it is waiting for us, besieging us on all sides. We will not find it in myths - although human facts carry with them a long and magnificent procession of legends, tales and songs, poems and dances. All we need do is simply to open our eyes, to leave the dark world of metaphysics and the false depths of the 'inner life' behind, and we will discover the immense human wealth that the humblest facts of everyday life contain.
author: Henri Lefebvre

solution: Capitalism could appropriate even the most radical ideas and return them safely in the form of harmless ideologies.
author: Guy Debord

solution: A person may cause evil to others not only by his actions but by his inaction, and in either case he is justly accountable to them for the injury.
author: John Stuart Mill

solution: It is part of the irony of life that the strongest feelings of devoted gratitude of which human nature seems to be susceptible, are called forth in human beings towards those who, having the power entirely to crush their earthly existence, voluntarily refrain from using that power.
author: John Stuart Mill

solution: Ha! to forget. How childish! I feel you in my bones. Your silence screams in my ears. You may nail your mouth shut, you may cut out your tongue, can you keep yourself from existing? Will you stop your thoughts.
source: No Exit and Three Other Plays
author: Jean-Paul Sartre

solution: Only in imaginary experience (in the folk tale, for example), which neutralizes the sense of social realities, does the social world take the form of a universe of possibles equally possible for any possible subject.
author: Pierre Bourdieu

solution: Consider this table in front of us, which has hitherto roused but the slightest thought in us. It is full of surprising possibilities. The one thing we know is that it is not what it seems. Beyond this modest result, we have the most complete liberty of conjecture. Leibniz tells us it is a community of souls; Bishop Berkeley tells us it is an idea in the mind of God; sober science, scarcely less wonderful, tells us it is a vast collection of electric charges in violent motion.
author: Bertrand Russell

solution: Those who wish to seek out the cause of miracles and to understand the things of nature as philosophers, and not to stare at them in astonishment like fools, are soon considered heretical and impious, and proclaimed as such by those whom the mob adores as the interpreters of nature and the gods. For these men know that, once ignorance is put aside, that wonderment would be taken away, which is the only means by which their authority is preserved.
author: Baruch Spinoza

solution: ‘True’ and ‘false’ are attributes of speech, not of things. And where speech is not, there is neither ‘truth’ nor ‘falsehood.
author: Thomas Hobbes

solution: The Bible is very easy to understand. But we Christians are a bunch of scheming swindlers. We pretend to be unable to understand it because we know very well that the minute we understand, we are obliged to act accordingly.
author: Søren Kierkegaard

solution: Capital is no longer the invisible center governing the production process; as it accumulates, it spreads to the ends of the earth in the form of tangible objects. The entire expanse of society is its portrait.
author: Guy Debord

solution: Abstract ideas are conceptual integrations which subsume an incalculable number of concretes - and without abstract ideas you would not be able to deal with concrete, particular, real-life problems. You would be in the position of a new born infant
author: Ayn Rand

solution: Even despotism does not produce its worst effects, so long as individuality exists under it; and whatever crushes individuality is despotism, by whatever name it may be called, and whether it professes to be enforcing the will of God or the injunctions of men.
author: John Stuart Mill

solution: There is only one really serious philosophical question,and that is suicide. Deciding whether or not life is worth living is to answer the fundamental question in philosophy.
author: Albert Camus

solution: My thought is me: that's why I can't stop. I exist because I think… and I can't stop myself from thinking. At this very moment - it's frightful - if I exist, it is because I am horrified at existing. I am the one who pulls myself from the nothingness to which I aspire.
author: Jean-Paul Sartre

solution: Courage consists, however, in agreeing to flee rather than live tranquilly and hypocritically in false refuges. Values, morals, homelands, religions, and these private certitudes that our vanity and our complacency bestow generously on us, have many deceptive sojourns as the world arranges for those who think they are standing straight and at ease, among stable things.
author: Gilles Deleuze
